accessibilityStatement.title: Accessibility statement for GOV.UK One Login
accessibilityStatement.header: Accessibility statement for GOV.UK One Login

content.paragraph1: GOV.UK One Login is part of the wider GOV.UK website. There’s a separate
content.linkText: accessibility statement for the main GOV.UK website

paragraph2.text1: This page contains information about the GOV.UK One Login service, available at
paragraph2.text2: and the user support webchat available at

paragraph1.text1: GOV.UK One Login is run by the
paragraph1.text2: , part of the Cabinet Office. We want as many people as possible to be able to use GOV.UK One Login. This means you should be able to:

usingOneLogin.bulletPoint1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
usingOneLogin.bulletPoint2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
usingOneLogin.bulletPoint3: navigate most of GOV.UK One Login using just a keyboard
usingOneLogin.bulletPoint4: navigate most of GOV.UK One Login using speech recognition software
usingOneLogin.bulletPoint5: listen to most of the content in GOV.UK One Login using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
usingOneLogin.paragraph2: We’ve also made the text in GOV.UK One Login as simple as possible to understand.
usingOneLogin.paragraph3: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

accessibilityOfOneLogin.header: How accessible GOV.UK One Login is

service.header: Accessibility issues on the GOV.UK One Login service
service.paragraph1: The following parts of GOV.UK One Login website are not fully accessible:
service.bulletPoint1: it’s not possible to stop or change the length of the time-out when you use, sign in to or create a GOV.UK One Login
service.bulletPoint2: it’s not possible for a screen reader to know when the emails we send are in a language other than English
service.bulletPoint3: one page reloads automatically after a set time limit, and it’s not possible to stop or delay this
service.bulletPoint4: the header sign-out link causes a horizontal scrollbar at very large magnifications on mobile devices
service.bulletPoint5: it’s not always possible to use your browser’s autocomplete options to enter information
service.bulletPoint6: the links in the footer are not the same on every page
service.bulletPoint7: there is an empty link in the header for a short section of the journey
service.bulletPoint8: some pages do not correctly identify the language they are published in
service.bulletPoint9: some page titles do not start with ‘error’ if you have not entered the information that’s needed in the correct format
service.bulletPoint10: some links in the header and footer that you may expect to open in a new tab open in the same tab
service.bulletPoint11: some form fields limit how many characters can be entered in them, which can make it difficult to enter information when using assistive technologies
service.bulletPoint12: buttons that show ‘spinner’ animations do not adhere to your reduced motion settings
service.bulletPoint13: the information in the cookie banner content is not the same on all pages it appears on

link.text: technical details of the GOV.UK One Login service accessibility issues

webchat.header: Accessibility issues on the GOV.UK One Login webchat
webchat.paragraph1: The following parts of the GOV.UK One Login webchat are not fully accessible:
webchat.bulletPoint1: voice control software may not be able to accurately label webchat content:
webchat.subBulletPoint1: if you are using Safari you will need to use the ‘show grid’ functionality to use the webchat
webchat.subBulletPoint2: if you are using Chrome you may need to ask the computer to ‘hide numbers’ and ‘show numbers’ again to refresh the labelling of the content
webchat.bulletPoint2: it’s not possible to change language in the middle of a chat session – if you do, you will lose your chat history
webchat.bulletPoint3: it’s not possible to save your chat session to refer to later if you leave the contact page
webchat.bulletPoint4: if you are using an external keyboard, the focus may not reach the question and answer section of the webchat and could disappear completely
webchat.bulletPoint5: some browsers move the keyboard focus to the start of the webchat when new content is added
webchat.bulletPoint6: if you are using a screen reader, it may be difficult to distinguish between answer options when they are first added to the webchat
webchat.bulletPoint7: sometimes the answer text is not descriptive enough when read out of context in the webchat
webchat.bulletPoint8: the form field label is temporarily removed when you are typing a response – the field label is replaced when you send your response
webchat.bulletPoint9: focus returns to the webchat icon after the webchat is closed, even if you start the webchat from the link in page content
webchat.bulletPoint10: if you are using a screen reader, the webchat will not confirm it has been closed

link.text: technical details of the GOV.UK One Login webchat accessibility issues

accessibilityOfOneLogin.updatesParagraph: We’ll update this page when issues are fixed or with information about when we plan to fix them.

enforcement.paragraph1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’).
enforcement.paragraph2: If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
enforcement.linkText: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS)

technicalInformation.header: Technical information about GOV.UK One Login’s accessibility
technicalInformation.paragraph1: The Government Digital Service is committed to making GOV.UK One Login accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

paragraph2.text1: GOV.UK One Login is partially compliant with the
paragraph2.text2: AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.

nonAccessibleContent.paragraph1: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.

service.header: Non compliance with the accessibility regulations for the GOV.UK One Login service
service.listItem1: When you create a GOV.UK One Login or sign in, if you do not do anything for 60 minutes, the process will stop (time out) or you’ll be signed out. It’s not possible to adjust, extend or turn off the time out. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.2.1 (Timing Adjustable).
service.listItem2: The header sign-out link causes a horizontal scrollbar at very large magnifications on mobile devices. If you use assistive technologies you may find it harder to navigate pages if you increase the zoom level. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 1.4.10 (Reflow).
service.listItem3: It’s not always possible to use your browser’s autocomplete options to enter information. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 1.3.5 (Identity Input Purpose).
service.listItem4: If you use assistive technologies, it may take you longer to enter information. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 1.3.5 (Identity Input Purpose).
service.listItem5: The links in the footer are not the same on every page. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.2.6 (Consistent Help).
service.listItem6: There is an empty link in the header for a short section of the journey. If you use assistive technologies you may be aware of the link but will not be able to select it. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.2.3 (Consistent Navigation).
service.listItem7: Some pages do not correctly identify the language they are published in. This means screen readers will not read content correctly. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.1.1 (Language of Page).
service.listItem8: Some page titles do not start with ‘error’ if the user hasn’t entered the information that’s needed in the correct format. This means screen reader users do not immediately know there is a problem. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.4.2 (Page Titled).
service.listItem9: Links in the header and footer that you may expect to open in a new tab sometimes open in the same tab. This fails WCAG 2.2 Guideline 3.2 (Predictable).
service.listItem10: Some form fields limit how many characters can be entered, which can make it difficult to enter information if you are using assistive technologies. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.3.1 (Error Identification).
service.listItem11: Buttons that show ‘spinner’ animations do not adhere to your reduced motion settings. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.2.2 (Pause, Stop, Hide).
service.listItem12: The information in the cookie banner content is not the same on all pages it appears on. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.2.6 (Consistent Help).

webchat.header: Non compliance with the accessibility regulations for the GOV.UK One Login webchat
webchat.listItem1: Voice control software may not be able to accurately label the webchat content. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 4.1.2 (Name, role, value).
webchat.listItem2: If you are using an external keyboard on mobile devices, the keyboard focus may not reach the question and answer section and could disappear completely. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.1.1 (Keyboard) and WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.1.2 (No keyboard trap).
webchat.listItem3: Some browsers move the chat keyboard focus to the start of the chat when new chat content is added. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.4.3 (Focus order).
webchat.listItem4: If you are using a screen reader, it may be difficult to distinguish between the different quick answer options provided by the webchat. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 1.3.1 (Info and relationships).
webchat.listItem5: Sometimes the answer text in buttons is not descriptive enough out of context. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.4.6 (Headings and labels).
webchat.listItem6: The field label is removed from the form when you type your own response to a message, but is replaced when you press return. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.3.2 (Labels and instructions).
webchat.listItem7: Focus returns to the webchat icon after the webchat is closed, even if you start the webchat from the link in page content. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.4.3 (Focus order).
webchat.paragraph1: There are three issues that we do not believe are non-compliant with accessibility regulations but may be frustrating for users:
webchat.bulletPoint1: it’s not possible to change language in the middle of a chat session
webchat.bulletPoint2: it’s not possible to save your chat session
webchat.bulletPoint3: the webchat does not confirm it has been closed to screen reader users

whatWereDoing.header: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
whatWereDoing.paragraph1: We’ll update this page when issues are fixed, when we expect them to be fixed or when new problems are identified.

preparation.paragraph1: This statement was prepared on 4 November 2020. It was last reviewed on 5 June 2024.
preparation.paragraph2: GOV.UK One Login was last tested in October and November 2023. The test was carried out by the GOV.UK One Login accessibility team who produced an audit of the journey in December 2023. The GOV.UK One Login accessibility team assessed GOV.UK One Login against the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2 in preparation for the guidelines being enforced in October 2024.
preparation.paragraph3: The GOV.UK One Login webchat service was last tested in April 2024. An initial audit was carried out by the GOV.UK One Login accessibility team in October 2023. The service was audited by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) in January 2024. The DAC audit assessed the webchat service against WCAG 2.1, but all success criteria failures also apply to WCAG 2.2.

termsAndConditions.header: GOV.UK One Login terms and conditions

Pages that are part of GOV.UK One Login have urls containing account.gov.uk. If you are using other parts of GOV.UK you should also read the

paragraph2.text2: (GDS) on behalf of the Crown. GDS is part of the Cabinet Office and will be referred to as ‘we’ from now on.

paragraph3.text3: before using GOV.UK One Login. The privacy notice explains the terms on which we process any personal data we collect from you or that you provide to us. The cookie policy gives information about the cookies we use and how we use them when you use GOV.UK One Login.

You should use a device that uses a Windows, OS, iOS or Android operating system. We recommend you use one of the following browsers:
section2.bulletPoint1: The latest version of Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Mozilla Firefox, Samsung Internet or Internet Explorer

For example you should choose a strong password and ensure you keep it secure. The UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) provides

section4.bulletPoint5: comply with all technology control or export laws that apply to the technology used by GOV.UK One Login
section4.paragraph3: You must not use GOV.UK One Login:

section4.bulletPoint14: in connection with any kind of denial of service attack or for any malicious purpose
section4.bulletPoint15: with someone else’s registered details, unless you have the authority to do so from them
section4.paragraph4: If you breach any of these terms and conditions, we may stop you from accessing your GOV.UK One Login and may take action to enforce these terms and conditions and take other action as appropriate where we have suffered loss. If, by doing any of the above acts, you are also committing a criminal offence, we may report it to the relevant law enforcement authorities. We may cooperate with those authorities by disclosing your identity to them.

paragraph1.text2: We’ll keep a record of certain information, in line with our

If any provision in these terms and conditions is invalid or unenforceable according to applicable law, we will replace it with a valid and enforceable provision that most closely matches the intent of the original. about.paragraph_one: GOV.UK One Login provides a single way to sign in and prove your identity when accessing government services online.

paragraph_two.part_one: GOV.UK One Login is provided by the
paragraph_two.part_three: , part of the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology (DSIT).

about.paragraph_three: Mentions of ‘us’ and ‘we’ in this privacy notice refer to GDS.
about.paragraph_four: The Department for Science, Innovation and Technology (DSIT), as GDS’s parent organisation, is the data controller of the personal data you provide when you use GOV.UK One Login. This means that DSIT is ultimately responsible for the personal data we collect and process on GOV.UK One Login. This includes determining things like what personal data should be collected, from whom, and what it will be used for.
about.paragraph_five: Other government departments are responsible for any personal data you provide when you use their online services. For example they may collect data from you either before they redirect you to GOV.UK One Login or after GOV.UK One Login returns you to their service, after you’ve completed your authentication or identity checks. This means that they are data controllers for that information and will decide what data to collect from you, why they need that data and how long they keep that data for. Details of this will be in their own privacy notices.

information_we_collect.paragraph_one: When you are referred to GOV.UK One Login by an online government service to sign in or prove your identity we will know what service you have come from.
information_we_collect.paragraph_two: The information we then collect from you will depend on:

list.item_one: whether the online government service is using GOV.UK One Login solely to log you in to their system or to prove your identity as well
list.item_two: the evidence and documents you have available to prove your identity
list.item_three: the type of device you use, for example a laptop, tablet or smartphone

information_we_collect.paragraph_three: In all cases, we will create a GOV.UK One Login using your email address. Where you choose to receive authentication codes using text message, we will also collect your phone number.
information_we_collect.paragraph_four: If the online government service is only using GOV.UK One Login to sign you in to their service, we will not collect any further information from you.
information_we_collect.paragraph_five: Where online government services use GOV.UK One Login to prove your identity, we need to conduct identity checks and therefore process additional personal data. The process includes a fraud check with Experian to make sure the data you give us is accurate and to check there are no signs your identity has been stolen or misused.
information_we_collect.paragraph_six: There are 3 main ways to prove your identity. The things we check depend on which way you prove your identity.

using_id_check_app.header: Using the GOV.UK ID Check app to prove your identity

paragraph_one.part_one: This route uses the GOV.UK ID Check app which is available to smartphone users through the
paragraph_one.part_three: app stores. It consists of a sequence of checks that are carried out  by specialist identity checking service providers on our behalf, as well as the fraud check described below.

list_one.item_two: you are a real person (also known as a ‘liveness’ check)
list_one.item_three: you are the same person as in the document photos (also known as a ‘likeness’ check)

using_id_check_app.paragraph_three: We use an identity checking service provider called Iproov and their subcontractors Veriff and Inverid to conduct these checks. Iproov acts as a data processor with Veriff and Inverid as sub-processors, which means that they may only process your personal data for the sole purpose of fulfilling our instructions.
using_id_check_app.sub_header_one: Information we may collect to check your documents are real
using_id_check_app.paragraph_four: We need to check your identity document security features to prove that they are genuine documents.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_five: For driving licences, you will need to take a photo of the front and back of your licence with your phone camera. The app will require permission to access your camera and photos for this.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_six: For e-passports, biometric residence permits and cards, and frontier worker permits the app will read your document information from its near field communication (NFC) chip.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_seven: We may collect the following information:
using_id_check_app.paragraph_eight: When Iproov has completed the check, they send us the outcome of the check and your identity document information.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_nine: If you use a driving licence, you’ll be able to check that the app has correctly captured the details.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_ten: You’ll need to agree to us sharing your details with:

list_three.item_one: the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) if your licence was issued in Great Britain
list_three.item_two: the Driver and Vehicle Agency (DVA) if your licence was issued in Northern Ireland

using_id_check_app.paragraph_eleven: They will check the information you’ve provided matches what’s in their records.
using_id_check_app.sub_header_two: Using a selfie video to check you are a real person
using_id_check_app.paragraph_twelve: We also do a ‘liveness’ check to prove whether you are a real person and not anything that might impersonate an individual such as a mannequin, wax figure, 3D mask, picture or deepfake.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_thirteen: You will need to take a selfie video using your phone camera. The app will require permission to access your camera and videos for this. This check is conducted in real-time which means that neither we nor Iproov store the video.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_fourteen: When Iproov has completed the check, they send us the outcome of the check.
using_id_check_app.sub_header_four: How we check you are the person in your photo
using_id_check_app.paragraph_fifteen: We do a ‘likeness’ check to prove that you are the same person as in your identity document photo.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_sixteen: This check uses a still image generated from your selfie video and your identity document photo to measure the unique patterns of your face. This is called facial biometric data. The biometric data from both images is compared to establish whether you are the actual owner of the identity document.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_seventeen: When Iproov has completed the check, they send us the outcome of the check.

using_web_to_prove_identity.header: Using your web browser to prove your identity
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_one: The checks we carry out depend on whether you have a photo ID like a passport or driving licence and what government service you are accessing. We also carry out the fraud check described below.
using_web_to_prove_identity.sub_header_one: How we check your photo ID
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_two: If you have photo ID like a passport or driving licence, we’ll check the details are genuine using the authoritative datasets held, respectively, by:

list_one.item_two: DVLA or DVA, depending on if your driving licence was issued in Great Britain or Northern Ireland

using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_three: You will need to provide your driving licence or passport details which we then send to HMPO, DVLA or DVA to validate against their records.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_four: When HMPO, DVLA or DVA have completed their checks, they tell us whether the data matches or not and if not, the reason why it didn’t match.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_five: HMPO, DVLA and DVA do so as independent data controllers in accordance with their privacy notices.
using_web_to_prove_identity.sub_header_two: How we check your bank details
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_six: If you prove your identity without photo ID, we may ask you to provide your name and the account number and sort code of a UK current bank account in your name.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_seven: We then check your UK current account details against the details held by banks across the UK, using a checking service provided by Experian.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_eight: When Experian have completed the check, they tell us:

list_two.item_one: whether the information you provided matches or not
list_two.item_two: where the name you provided is a partial match to banking records, the official name on record

using_web_to_prove_identity.sub_header_three: How we check your HMRC record
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_nine: If you prove your identity without photo ID, we may also ask you to provide your National Insurance number. We share your National Insurance number, name, postcode and date of birth with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), who check if they have a record of you and that the information matches what you told us.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_ten: When HMRC have completed the check, they confirm to us whether the information you provided matches their records or not.
using_web_to_prove_identity.sub_header_four: What information we collect when you answer security questions

paragraph_eleven.part_one: We ask you security questions, also known as a ‘knowledge based verification’ (‘KBV’) check, using questions about your credit or financial history that only you should know the answer to. This check is conducted by Experian as an independent data controller in accordance with their

using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_twelve: For this check we use your name, date of birth and address to retrieve relevant questions from Experian. We collect your answers and send them to Experian to check that they match the information they already have about you.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_thirteen: When Experian has completed the check they respond to us with a Pass / Fail outcome.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_fourteen: GDS does not store or retain the questions or your answers.

proving_identity_at_post_office.header: Proving your identity at a Post Office
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_one: GOV.UK One Login gives you the option to prove your identity at a Post Office. This route consists of a sequence of checks carried out by specialist identity checking services on our behalf, as well as the fraud check described below.

list_one.item_two: you are the same person as in the identity document photos (also known as a ‘likeness’ check)

proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_three: These checks are conducted by the Post Office and their subcontractor Yoti on our behalf. The Post Office acts as a data processor with Yoti as a sub-processor, which means that they may only process your personal data for the sole purpose of fulfilling our instructions.
proving_identity_at_post_office.sub_header_one: What information we collect before you go to the Post Office
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_four: We ask you what identity document you would like to use to prove your identity. You can use any of the following identity documents:

list_two.item_five: National identity card from the EU, Norway, Iceland or Liechtenstein

list_three.item_one: for your identity document’s expiry date and issuing country
list_three.item_two: to confirm that the address you provided previously matches the address shown on your identity document, for documents that have an address on them.
list_three.item_three: to choose which Post Office branch you would like to attend

proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_six: We send this information plus your name, address and date of birth to the Post Office before you go to a branch. We also send you an email with a link to download a Post Office In Branch Verification customer letter. This will contain a QR code and instructions about what you will need to do next. You will need to open the link, enter your email address, and download and print the letter and take it with you when you attend the Post Office, or show it on your device.
proving_identity_at_post_office.sub_header_two: What information we collect at the Post Office
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_seven: When you attend the Post Office, a member of staff will scan the QR code on your letter and check the identity document you have with you against the details you provided.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_eight: The Post Office and Yoti will then check your identity document security features to make sure it is a genuine document.

list_four.item_one: For all identity documents, the Post Office will take a photo of the front and back of the document to check the document’s security features, such as holograms, and to read the document information.
list_four.item_two: For UK e-passports, the Post Office will also use a tablet to check your document’s security features and to read your document information from the NFC chip.

proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_nine: The Post Office will also take a photo of your face, from which they will measure the unique patterns of your face. This is called facial biometric data. The biometric data from your photo will be compared against the biometric data from the photo on your identity document to check whether you are the actual owner of the identity document.
proving_identity_at_post_office.sub_header_three: What happens after your Post Office visit
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_ten: When the Post Office and Yoti have completed the checks, they send us the result of the check and your identity document information.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_eleven: We then use your email address to tell you that the results of your check are available. To see your result and share it with the service you needed to prove your identity for, you will need to sign in to GOV.UK One Login and be redirected to the government service you were using.

borrow_phone_identity.header: If you let somebody borrow your phone to prove their identity
borrow_phone_identity.paragraph_one: Technical information about the device being used will be collected by GOV.UK One Login as set out below.

handle_information.header: How we handle your information to check against fraud
handle_information.paragraph_one: However you prove your identity, we will run an online fraud check using an identity checking service provider called Experian to:

list.item_one: look for any signs that your identity has been stolen or misused
list.item_two: check whether there is a record of you existing over time

paragraph_two.part_one: They do this as an independent data controller in accordance with the

handle_information.paragraph_three: We collect your name, date of birth and address and send them to Experian so they can conduct the check.
handle_information.paragraph_four: When Experian has completed the check, they send us a fraud score, based on any potential or associated fraudulent activity. If you have concerns involving potential fraud of your identity data, you should contact Experian directly, as the independent controller of this search data.
handle_information.paragraph_five: This fraud check will not affect your credit score, as it is a ‘soft search’. An entry about it will be added to your credit record, but it will only be visible to you. Other organisations that use Experian to run their own credit checks will not be able to see it.

technical_information.paragraph_one: We collect technical information as an integral part of providing GOV.UK One Login to you. This includes:

list.item_one: online identifiers, like your Internet Protocol (IP) addresses
list.item_two: technical information about the device you use such as the model, web browser operating system and unique device ID
list.item_three: This data is stored in system audit and security logs for system and security monitoring and technical troubleshooting purposes.

technical_information.paragraph_two: This data is stored in system audit and security logs for system and security monitoring and technical troubleshooting purposes.

when_you_contact_us.header: When you contact us for help or to provide feedback

paragraph_one.part_one: There are a number of ways to contact us if you need help with GOV.UK One Login. They are on the

when_you_contact_us.paragraph_two: If you contact us for help, we will collect:

list.item_one: information about you such as your name, telephone number and email address, and use this information to contact you about your enquiry and to identify your GOV.UK One Login if necessary
list.item_two: the details of your help request
list.item_three: your preferred language (English or Welsh) so we can contact you in that language

when_you_contact_us.paragraph_three: When you contact us do not include any sensitive or financial information about yourself. If you choose to share details about yourself to give extra context for your enquiry, we will store that information in our systems.
when_you_contact_us.paragraph_four: We store recordings of all telephone conversations. We use these for monitoring and detecting fraud, resolving complaints, quality monitoring and training, and improving our service.
when_you_contact_us.paragraph_five: If you contact us through our web form, we collect technical information about your device as outlined in the ‘Technical information‘ section of this notice.
when_you_contact_us.paragraph_six: If you agree to take part in our survey about the help you received, we collect your answers to the questions. These are linked to the record of when you contacted us, which includes information such as your name, email address or telephone number.

if_you_agree_to_analytics.header: If you agree to web or app analytics (cookies)

paragraph_one.part_one: We use Google Analytics and Dynatrace to collect information about how you use GOV.UK One Login. These is done using cookies. Cookies are small files saved on your phone, tablet or computer when you visit a website. Our cookie privacy notice and consent process is set out in the

if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_two: Some cookies are strictly necessary for GOV.UK One Login to support authentication and security.
if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_three: Further cookies support our analysis of the platform and allows GOV.UK One Login to improve the citizen experience. These cookies will require your consent.

list.item_one: information about the pages you use
list.item_two: how long you spend on each page
list.item_three: how you got to GOV.UK One Login
list.item_four: what you click on while you use the service
list.item_six: an indication of your location (such as your city and country) using your anonymised IP address
list.item_eight: if you see any error messages
list.item_nine: technical information including your IP address and a unique identifier, and the type of device and web browser you use

if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_five: The information collected is classed as personal data because Google Analytics and Dynatrace assign a unique identifier to each visitor. This does not however enable us or Google to determine your real world identity. We will also not combine analytics information with the data you provide when authenticating your GOV.UK One Login or proving your identity or any other data that we may hold in order to determine your real world identity.
if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_six: We also use Firebase Crashlytics to collect information about problems you may experience when you use the GOV.UK ID Check app, such as the app crashing.
if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_seven: In all  cases, Google, Dynatrace and Firebase Crashlytics act as our data processor and we do not allow them to use or share this data for their own purposes.

why_we_need_your_information.paragraph_one: We collect your personal information on GOV.UK One Login to:

list_one.item_one: provide you with a GOV.UK One Login to access online government services

why_we_need_your_information.paragraph_two: We also use your information to:

list_two.item_one: keep your GOV.UK One Login secure (using your email address, phone number, password and system logs)
list_two.item_two: store your proven identity information within GOV.UK One Login to enable you to reuse it
list_two.item_four: provide the government service(s) that you access through GOV.UK One Login with information about the outcome of your identity check
list_two.item_five: provide you with a record of how your GOV.UK One Login has been used, for example, when it was last signed in to and what services it has been used with
list_two.item_six: contact you about any planned interruptions, problems or changes that may affect your GOV.UK One Login (using your email address)
list_two.item_seven: improve the service by understanding how you use it and any problems you experience, for example using Google Analytics, Firebase Crashlytics, Dynatrace, and the contact centre feedback survey
list_two.item_eight: monitor the rates of successful and unsuccessful identity checking submissions and produce anonymised reports about GOV.UK One Login to help us understand where we can make improvements
list_two.item_nine: help diagnose and fix technical or debugging issues
list_two.item_ten: assist in billing and reconciliation for the third party identity checking services we use
list_two.item_eleven: monitor the system for security threats and system issues, for example outages.

legal_basis.header: Our legal basis for processing your information
legal_basis.paragraph_one: When we process your personal data for security monitoring purposes, the legal basis we rely on is that the processing is necessary for GDS’s legitimate interests. GDS interests in this regard are protecting GOV.UK One Login and its users against security threats.
legal_basis.paragraph_two: We obtain your consent to process your personal data for the following purposes:

list_one.item_one: collecting and analysing information about how you use your GOV.UK One Login using Google Analytics and Dynatrace cookies
list_one.item_two: collecting and processing your responses to our survey about the help you received

legal_basis.paragraph_three: Where we rely on consent we will explain as clearly and concisely as possible how your data will be processed so you understand what you are consenting to. If you later change your mind, you can withdraw your consent at any time. How you can do this will depend on what we are processing your data for. For example, you can:

item_one.part_one: withdraw your consent from our use of cookies using the GOV.UK One Login

item_two.part_one: click the unsubscribe link on emails you receive from us, or you can contact

legal_basis.paragraph_four: For all other purposes including the administration of your GOV.UK One Login, proving your identity and enabling you to reuse that proven identity, and fraud monitoring, the legal basis is that it is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or the exercise of our functions as a government department.
legal_basis.paragraph_five: If you prove your identity using the GOV.UK Identity Check app, you will do a likeness check which will involve processing your facial biometric data. Under UK Law, biometric data is classed as special category data and DSIT is required to have an additional legal basis to process it. DSIT processes biometric data on the legal basis that the processing is necessary for reasons of substantial public interest. UK Law also requires DSIT to meet a specific substantial public interest condition from the UK Data Protection Act 2018. DSIT relies on the following 2 conditions:

list_three.item_one: statutory and government purposes for identity checking (paragraph 6, schedule 1, Data Protection Act 2018)
list_three.item_two: preventing or detecting unlawful acts for fraud detection and prevention (paragraph 10, schedule 1, Data Protection Act 2018)

legal_basis.paragraph_six: We ask that you do not share any sensitive information about yourself when you contact us for help or to give feedback. If you choose to provide such information we process it on the legal basis that the processing is necessary for reasons of substantial public interest. In addition we rely on the statutory and government purposes condition in the Data Protection Act 2018.

who_we_share_with.header: Who we share your information with
who_we_share_with.sub_header_one: Sharing your information with online government services and the departments that run them
who_we_share_with.paragraph_one: When you sign in or prove your identity with GOV.UK One Login, we send the online government service that you are trying to access the following information:

list_one.item_one: the result of your identity check
list_one.item_three: information that enables the other government service to match you against their records, which typically includes your name, date of birth and address

who_we_share_with.paragraph_two: Other government services process the data we share with them as independent data controllers under a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) we have with them. Each online government service will have its own terms and conditions and privacy notice. You should read these as well as the GOV.UK One Login terms and conditions and this privacy notice, so that you understand how your personal information is managed.
who_we_share_with.paragraph_three: Government Gateway is HMRC’s own authentication and identity checking service that enables users to access tax and other services. The GOV.UK ID Check app is integrated into the Government Gateway service, as well as into GOV.UK One Login, and therefore the personal data processing outlined in the relevant sections of this privacy notice applies to Government Gateway users of the app.
who_we_share_with.paragraph_four: Additionally, HMRC conducts their own identity document checks against authoritative government data sources. We therefore share your driving licence and passport information with HMRC to enable them to conduct these checks.
who_we_share_with.paragraph_five: We share the following information from your driving licence with Government Gateway:
who_we_share_with.paragraph_six: We share the following information from your passport with Government Gateway:

list_three.item_six: International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) Issuer code

who_we_share_with.paragraph_seven: HMRC processes this data as an independent data controller under a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) we have with them under and in accordance with their own privacy policies.
who_we_share_with.sub_header_two: Sharing your information to prove your identity
who_we_share_with.paragraph_eight: We engage specialist third party identity service providers to conduct individual identity checks on our behalf. We share your personal information with these service providers to enable them to conduct the checks.

item_one.part_one: His Majesty’s Passport Office (HMPO), as an independent data controller under an MoU, to conduct passport genuine document checks; read

item_two.part_one: the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA), as an independent data controller under an MoU, for GB driving licence genuine document checks; read

item_three.part_one: the Driver and Vehicle Agency Northern Ireland (DVA NI), as an independent data controller under an MoU, for Northern Irish driving licence genuine document checks; see

item_four.part_one: Experian, as an independent data controller subject to a contract with us, for checking answers to security questions, bank account checks and fraud checks;  read

list_four.item_five: iProov, as a data processor with Veriff and Inverid  as its sub-processors, subject to a contract with us, for biometric likeness checks, genuine document checks and liveness checks
list_four.item_six: Post Office, as a data processor with Yoti as its sub-processor, subject to a contract with us, for in-person identity checks

item_seven.part_one: HMRC as an independent data controller under an MoU, for bank account checks;  read more in

who_we_share_with.paragraph_ten: In all cases we only provide the minimum information needed to perform the checks.
who_we_share_with.sub_header_three: Sharing your information to protect against fraud
who_we_share_with.paragraph_eleven: To protect against crime and fraud, we sometimes need to share information with:

list_five.item_one: government departments that run the services you access though your GOV.UK One Login
list_five.item_two: other public sector organisations, such as the Home Office
list_five.item_five: data processors who provide relevant monitoring services

who_we_share_with.paragraph_twelve: The information we may share includes:

list_six.item_four: location, derived from the IP address and expressed as a country, for example ‘GB’
list_six.item_six: information about the devices being used, including device ID
list_six.item_seven: identity document details, including name and date of birth

who_we_share_with.paragraph_thirteen: Where we have a concern about fraudulent activity, we might also share details from:
who_we_share_with.paragraph_fourteen: This information we share may have been provided by you to GOV.UK One Login directly. Or it may have been shared with us by government services that run the services you have accessed through GOV.UK One Login, or third parties such as credit reference agencies such as Experian.
who_we_share_with.sub_header_four: Sharing your information with our suppliers
who_we_share_with.paragraph_fifteen: We work with technology suppliers, for example we use an external hosting provider and a contact centre provider. We only give our suppliers access to your information if they need it to provide their service. Our suppliers act as data processors and are subject to contracts with us which restrict them to only processing your personal data for the sole purpose of providing their services in accordance with our instructions.

how_long_we_keep_your_information.header: How long we keep your information
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_one: We store your personal information for no longer than is reasonably necessary and legally justifiable.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_two: We will keep your GOV.UK One Login for as long as you wish to use it although we will delete it if you do not use it for 5 years.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_three: If you choose to delete your GOV.UK One Login, we’ll delete your account and your proven identity information.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_four: We delete your still photo generated from your selfie video, driving licence images and biometric facial data from Iproov’s systems after 30 days.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_five: The in-person identity check stores your data for 11 days to give you enough time to go to the Post Office to complete your identity check.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_six: We will store the information we collect when you contact us for help for one year. This includes call recordings.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_seven: We will keep your feedback data for 2 years.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_eight: We will store information about the actions you take when you use your GOV.UK One Login in system logs for 1 year.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_nine: We also maintain a secure audit trail of all GOV.UK One Login audit events and activity which we retain for 7 years for fraud monitoring purposes.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_ten: GDS does not store or retain the:

list_one.item_one: KBV questions we source from credit reference agencies or your answers to those questions
list_one.item_two: selfie video you take as part of proving your identity using the GOV.UK Identity Check app

how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_eleven: If you consented to analytics, Dynatrace will store information about how you used GOV.UK One Login for 35 days.

childrens_privacy_protection.paragraph_one: GOV.UK One Login is not designed for, or intentionally targeted at, children 13 years of age or younger. We do not intentionally collect or maintain information about anyone under the age of 13.

where_information_processed_stored.header: Where your information is processed and stored
where_information_processed_stored.paragraph_one: All personal data processed directly for the administration of your GOV.UK One Login and for identity checking is stored in the UK or in the European Economic Area (EEA). The EEA has been assessed by the UK Government as having adequate legal protections for data privacy in line with those in the UK.
where_information_processed_stored.paragraph_two: Data collected by Google Analytics or Dynatrace may be transferred outside the European Economic Area (EEA) for processing and some of our suppliers may provide technical support from outside of the EEA. In both cases, we make sure your information is just as well protected, for example by including extra clauses in our contracts with suppliers. Google is also supported by the US Data Privacy Framework, which extends to UK data protection and processing security.
where_information_processed_stored.paragraph_three: Where locations of processors or sub-processors are outside the UK, we rely on agreed model contract clauses set out by GDPR for assurance and data protection.

how_we_protect_your_information.header: How we protect your personal information and keep it secure
how_we_protect_your_information.paragraph_one: We are committed to doing all that we can to keep your information secure. We have set up systems and processes to prevent unauthorised access or disclosure of your information – for example, we use varying levels of encryption. We also make sure that any third parties that we deal with keep all personal information they process on our behalf secure.
how_we_protect_your_information.paragraph_two: As the owner of your GOV.UK One Login, you also have some responsibility for its security. For example, you should:

item_one.part_one: choose a strong password for your GOV.UK One Login and ensure you keep it secure - the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) provides
item_one.link_text: advice on keeping your online accounts secure

item_two.link_text: contact us immediately if you suspect that your account has been compromised

automated_decision_making.paragraph_one: GOV.UK’s identity checking process is fully automated and therefore the majority of identity checking decisions are based solely on automated processing.
automated_decision_making.paragraph_two: GOV.UK One Login determines what identity checks need to be conducted to prove your identity taking into account the:

list_one.item_one: level of confidence services need in your identity
list_one.item_two: evidence and documents you have available to prove your identity
list_one.item_three: type of device you use, for example a laptop, tablet or smartphone

automated_decision_making.paragraph_three: GOV.UK One Login then directs specialist third party identity service providers to conduct the necessary identity checking. Most of these checks are fully automated without any manual involvement. For the driving licence check conducted using the GOV.UK Identity Check app, if an automated decision cannot be made successfully, a manual checking process is then used.
automated_decision_making.paragraph_four: GOV.UK One Login receives a response from each identity service provider which contains the outcomes of their identity checks and decides whether the outcomes of the completed checks provide the required level of confidence in your identity.
automated_decision_making.paragraph_five: This process is fully automated and may result in users not having their identity proven to the level required by the online government service you are trying to access. If we are not able to confirm your identity we will show you a screen that notifies you of this, provides you with instructions on what you can do next and provides you with a way to contact us.
automated_decision_making.paragraph_six: Individuals or services can ask us to prove that the automated decision has been made correctly and we will generally prove that GOV.UK One Login is functioning as anticipated without error or bias. We may not be able to provide full information about individual identity checking attempts particularly where providing information would interfere with the prevention or detection of fraud or other crime.

paragraph_one.part_one: UK Data Protection Law provides you with a number of rights which you can exercise by contacting the

list_one.item_one: request a copy of your personal information that we hold
list_one.item_two: ask us to change your information if it is wrong or inaccurate
list_one.item_three: ask us to delete your information, although we may not be able to delete your information if there is a legal reason for us to retain it
list_one.item_four: request a restriction on our use of your information. For example where it is wrong or inaccurate and you would like it to be changed before being used again
list_one.item_five: object about how we process your personal data where we process it under the public task or legitimate interests lawful bases
list_one.item_six: withdraw your consent where we process your personal data with your consent

contact_us_or_make_complaint.header: Contact us or make a complaint

list_one.item_one: have a question about anything in this privacy notice
list_one.item_two: think that your personal information has been misused or mishandled
list_one.item_three: want to make a ‘subject access request‘ to find out more about how your personal information is collected and used

contact_us_or_make_complaint.paragraph_two: You can also contact our Data Protection Officer (DPO) who provides independent advice and monitoring of our use of personal information:

data_protection_officer.title: Data Protection Officer at the GDS Privacy Office

information_commissioner.paragraph_one: You can also make a complaint to the Information Commissioner, who is an independent regulator.
information_commissioner.paragraph_two: Making a complaint to the Information Commissioner will not affect your rights.

changes_to_this_notice.paragraph_one: We may change this privacy notice. In that case, the ‘last updated’ date of this document will also change. Any changes to this privacy notice will apply to you and your information immediately.
changes_to_this_notice.paragraph_two: If these changes affect how your personal information is processed, GDS will let you know.

getSecurityCodes.title: Choose how to get security codes
getSecurityCodes.header: Choose how to get security codes
getSecurityCodes.summary: You’ll need to enter a security code when you sign in to GOV.UK One Login.
getSecurityCodes.titleAccountPartCreated: Finish creating your GOV.UK One Login
getSecurityCodes.headerAccountPartCreated: Finish creating your GOV.UK One Login
getSecurityCodes.summaryAccountPartCreated: Choose a way to get security codes when you sign in. This helps keep your GOV.UK One Login secure.

secondFactorRadios.authAppHintText: You can use any authenticator app to create security codes when you sign in
secondFactorRadios.errorMessage: Select how you want to get security codes

authAppDetails.paragraph1: An authenticator app creates a security code that helps confirm it’s you when you sign in.
authAppDetails.paragraph2: You can use an authenticator app on your smartphone, tablet or desktop computer.
authAppDetails.paragraph3: Download an authenticator app from your app store or search online for one you can use on your computer.

accountRecoveryVariants.title: How do you want to get security codes?
accountRecoveryVariants.header: How do you want to get security codes?
accountRecoveryVariants.summary: Choose how you’ll get security codes when signing in to your GOV.UK One Login. This will remove all methods you already have set up.

setupAuthenticatorApp.title: Set up an authenticator app
setupAuthenticatorApp.step1: Open your authenticator app on your smartphone, tablet or computer.

noAuthAppDetails.summaryText: I don’t have an authenticator app
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph1: You can download an authenticator app for your smartphone or tablet from your app store.
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph2: If you don’t have a smartphone or tablet, search online for an authenticator app for your computer.
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph3: You can use any authenticator app.

setupAuthenticatorApp.step2: Use your authenticator app to scan the QR code.

cannotScanDetails.summaryText: I cannot scan the QR code
cannotScanDetails.paragraph1: You can enter the secret key into your authenticator app instead.
cannotScanDetails.paragraph3: Some authenticator apps call the secret key a ‘code’.

setupAuthenticatorApp.step3: The authenticator app will show a security code.

signInRetryBlocked.title: You cannot sign in at the moment
signInRetryBlocked.header: You cannot sign in at the moment
signInRetryBlocked.paragraph: This is because you entered the wrong password more than 5 times the last time you tried to sign in. This is to keep your GOV.UK One Login secure.

bulletPointSection.title: You can:
bulletPointSection.second: wait 2 hours, then go back to the service you were trying to use and start again. You can look for the service using your search engine or find it from the GOV.UK homepage

needToResetPassword.title: You need to reset your password
needToResetPassword.header: You need to reset your password
needToResetPassword.paragraph1: To keep your GOV.UK One Login safe, you need to reset your password.
needToResetPassword.paragraph2: We’ll send a code to your email address, which you can use to reset your password.

permanentlyLockedScreen.title: Your GOV.UK One Login has been permanently locked
permanentlyLockedScreen.header: Your GOV.UK One Login has been permanently locked

section1.paragraph1: You cannot sign in and you cannot use your GOV.UK  One Login to access government services.

section2.heading: What you can do
section2.paragraph1: Go back to the service you were trying to use. You can look for the service using your search engine or find it from the GOV.UK  homepage.
section2.paragraph2: You can create a new GOV.UK  One Login with a different email address.

section1.paragraph1: Your GOV.UK  One Login is not available at the moment.

section2.heading: What you can do
section2.paragraph1: Come back later. Your GOV.UK  One Login should be available again in 3 working days.
section2.paragraph2: You can also go back to the service you were trying to use. You can look for the service using your search engine or find it from the GOV.UK homepage.

openOneLoginInWebBrowser.title: Open GOV.UK One Login in a web browser to continue
openOneLoginInWebBrowser.heading: Open GOV.UK One Login in a web browser to continue

section1.paragraph1: You’ll need to use a web browser to sign in to GOV.UK One Login. Then you can check if you can change how you get security codes.

section2.heading: Sign in using a web browser

bulletPointSection.bullet1: Open a web browser like Chrome or Safari.
bulletPointSection.bullet2: Copy this web address into the browser: gov.uk/account
bulletPointSection.bullet3: Enter your email address and password, then select ‘Check if you can change how you get security codes’.

section2.paragraph1: To continue after you’ve changed how you get security codes, you’ll need to sign back in to the app you’re using now.
